awd_titl_txt: PIRE: Science of Design for Societal-Scale Cyber-Physical Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
PI: Janos Sztipanovits, Vanderbilt University
Co-PIs: Shankar Sastry, UC Berkeley, Alexanmder Pretschner, Technical University of Munich and Werner Damm, University of Oldenburg

This project aims to develop a new Science of Design for societal-scale Cyber- Physical Systems (CPS). Emerging industrial platforms such as the Internet of Things (IoT), Industrial Internet (II) in the US and Industrie 4.0 in Europe have tremendously accelerated the development of new generations of CPS that integrate humans and human organizations with physical and computation processes (H-CPS) and extend to societal-scale systems such as traffic networks, electric grids, or networks of autonomous systems (self-driving cars, unmanned air vehicles) where control is dynamically shifted between humans and machines. Societal-scale systems are motivated by societal needs, but must conform to social norms and respond to expectations. If these systems evolve independently in the US and other countries, they will "hard-wire" the social context in which they are created, making interoperation hard or impossible, decreasing reusability of results, and narrowing markets for products and services. While impacts of new technology trends on social policies have received attention, the other side of the coin - to make systems adaptable to social policies - is nearly absent from engineering and computer science curricula and design practice. The project brings together a large, interdisciplinary group of researchers from Vanderbilt University, UC Berkeley, Technical University of Munich and University of Oldenburg working on integrated dynamics of humans, human organizations and networked CPS components, systems science foundations for resilient H-CPS, high-confidence design of H-CPS with learning enabled components, and social science. The goal of the project is to develop technologies that can be adapted to varying public policies. The international collaboration exposes students to H-CPS design which is strongly contextual and provides practical experience with the required scientific and technical foundations.  The education goal is to lay the foundation for and collect experience with new engineering and computer science education constructs that prepares students for the design and operation of a new generation of policy-aware H-CPS applications. The experience gained via the joint US and German research collaboration will be generalized and extended to broader international context.
The central technical goal of this joint research activity is to establish foundations for constructing H-CPS systems that can be parameterized by social context.  Our technical approach is three-fold: (1) Understand and compare the nature, scope, and evolution of policies and societal expectations in the operation of societal-scale H-CPS in the US and in Europe. The purpose of the analysis is not to shape social policies, but to determine which factors have the greatest influence on technical solutions. (2) Investigate methods for the explicit and formal representation of societal context (operational, privacy, safety, security policies, incentives, pricing and market policies) that are machine interpretable and impact the structure and behavior of H-CPS. (3) Develop policy-aware architectures that guarantee the enforcement of policy requirements during the operation of a new generation of H-CPS. The expected outcomes of the proposed research program are: (1) H-CPS architecture specifications that can be ?parameterized? by operational, safety and security policies, and by constraints emerging from societal expectations, (2) policy model repositories, (3) design tool chains, and (4) test beds. The international project team will evaluate research results in low-altitude air traffic control, smart-grid and intelligent transportation system testbeds.

por.por_cntn:
Initiatives in the U.S. and Europe accelerated the development of new generations of Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) that integrate humans with physical and computation processes, what we refer to as Human-Cyber-Physical Systems (H-CPS). These H-CPS extend to societal-scale systems such as traffic networks, electric grids, and networks of autonomous systems (e.g., self-driving cars, unmanned air vehicles) where control is dynamically shifted between humans and machines. Societal-scale systems are motivated by societal needs but must conform to social norms and respond to expectations. If these systems evolve independently in the US and other countries, they will “hard-wire” the social context in which they are created, making interoperation hard or impossible, decreasing reusability of results, and narrowing markets for products and services. While impacts of new technology trends on social policies have received attention, the other side of the coin – to make systems adaptable to social policies - is nearly absent from engineering and computer science curricula and design practice. The project brought together a large, interdisciplinary group of researchers from Vanderbilt University, UC Berkeley, Technical University of Munich and University of Oldenburg working on integrated dynamics of humans, human organizations and networked CPS components, systems science foundations for resilient H-CPS, high-confidence design of H-CPS with learning enabled components, and social science.

The technical goal of this joint international research activity was to establish foundations for constructing H-CPS systems that can be parameterized by social context.  Our approach was three-fold: (1) Understand and compare the nature, scope, and evolution of policies and societal expectations in the operation of societal-scale H-CPS in the US and in Europe. The purpose of the analysis is not to shape social policies, but to determine which factors have the greatest influence on technical solutions. (2) Investigate methods for the explicit and formal representation of societal context (operational, privacy, safety, security policies, incentives, pricing, and market policies) that are machine interpretable and impact the structure and behavior of H-CPS. (3) Develop H-CPS architectures that that can be “parameterized” by social context, that is systems motivated by societal needs that also conform to societal norms and respond to societal expectations.

Key technical outcomes:

  1. A team involving some 25 PIRE researchers from both the US and Germany, including highly renowned experts in Systems Engineering, Ethics, Ergonomics, Cognitive Psychology, HCI design, Social Sciences, Artificial Intelligence, Cyber-Physical Systems, Hybrid Systems, Game Theory, Safety, and Validation & Verification methods, cooperatively developed a reference architecture for safety-relevant Human-Cyber-Physical Systems. This architecture has been published as a series of three journal articles within the ACM Transactions on Cyber Physical Systems.
  2. Organization of three transatlantic workshops on highly automated vehicles (German Embassy, Washington DC, 2019), unmanned aerial vehicles (UC Berkeley, 2021), and autonomous and digitalized energy systems (University of Oldenburg, 2022). These workshops highlighted the relevance of the research jointly pursued and the approaches developed in the partner projects for the development of future societal-scale CPS.
  3. The team established annually a suite of research projects co-led by USA and German investigators and delivered results contributing to the scientific foundations of the design of societal-scale CPS publications, tools and testbeds.

The educational goal of the project was to expose students to H-CPS design which is strongly contextual and provide practical experience with the required scientific and technical foundations via their involvement in international collaboration. This education goal was to lay the foundation for and collect experience with new engineering and computer science education constructs that prepares students for the design and operation of a new generation of policy-aware H-CPS applications.

Key education outcomes:

  1. Development of and offering an international undergraduate seminar course on the Science of Design of Societal-Scale CPS. The course was taught by lead USA and German project researchers and exposed students to challenges caused by differing societal expectations toward transportation, energy and unmanned aerial vehicle systems. 
  2. A subset of participating students were selected for an international summer research internship wherein they selected topics from the research project portfolio and were embedded in international research teams. The experience was concluded with a final project report.

The PIRE program enabled cross-discipline and cross-country collaboration and the opportunity to take a deep dive into the challenges in designing and deploying CPS that address both technical and operational needs but also conform to societal norms and expectations. The work inspired a robust research exchange program that provided opportunities for students to spend extended periods of time in country with their European counterparts, giving them a better understanding of cultural and societal differences and commonalities.

The project culminated in a final workshop at TU Munich in June 2023 where we presented research results and findings and discussed commonalities and differences in the ways recommendations might be implemented in the U.S. and Europe, given the different approaches to technology policies and overall differences in societal values.
